‘No, of course not. Here, take this one, of cypress wood.’ 

Sonia held out the cross. 

‘It’s mine! It’s mine, you know,’ she begged. 

‘We will go to suffer together,’ she said. 

‘Give it me,’ Raskolnikov replied, reaching out. 

He hesitated, then withdrew his hand. 

‘Not now, Sonia. Better later.’ 

‘Yes, yes, better,’ she agreed. 

‘When you go to meet your suffering, then put it on.’ 

Suddenly, a knock came at the door. 

‘Sofya Semyonovna, may I come in?’ 

Sonia jumped up, startled. 

Mr. Lebeziatnikov’s flaxen head appeared.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Sonia offers Raskolnikov a cross to symbolize their shared suffering, but he hesitates to accept it immediately.
